values.description: Using a merged install simplifies the configuration of the `ign` tool. In my testing, `ign` works immediately after sourcing `local_setup.bash`. Without merge install, `IGN_CONFIG_PATH` has to be set to include the `share/<package>/ignition` of each package.
values.title: Use colcon merge install

summary.raw: Using a merged install simplifies the configuration of the `ign` tool. In my testing, `ign` works immediately after sourcing `local_setup.bash`. Without merge install, `IGN_CONFIG_PATH` has to be set to include the `share/<package>/ignition` of each package.
summary.html: Using a merged install simplifies the configuration of the ign tool. In my testing, ign works immediately after sourcing local_setup.bash. Without merge install, IGN_CONFIG_PATH has to be set to include the share/<package>/ignition of each package.

values.description:
Not sure if `list` and then `graph` is necessary, since `graph` shows both the libraries and interdependencies \(or should it just be `list`, forgetting the dependencies?\). 

Also wondering if a link to [colcon docs](https://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/released/reference/verb/graph.html#example-output) is a good idea for readers to be able to decode the interdpendency graph.
values.title: Change colcon list -g to colcon graph

summary.raw:
Not sure if `list` and then `graph` is necessary, since `graph` shows both the libraries and interdependencies \(or should it just be `list`, forgetting the dependencies?\). 

Also wondering if a link to [colcon docs](https://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/released/reference/verb/graph.html#example-output) is a good idea for readers to be able to decode the interdpendency graph.
summary.html:
Not sure if list and then graph is necessary, since graph shows both the libraries and interdependencies (or should it just be list, forgetting the dependencies?).

Also wondering if a link to colcon docs is a good idea for readers to be able to decode the interdpendency graph.

values.description:
This is the outline I came up with to organize the installation page better:

1. Option 1: Binary Installation

    1. Ubuntu Bionic
    2. MacOS Mojave \(10.14\)
    3. Using the workspace _\(finished, no jumps necessary\)_
    
2. Option 2: Source Installation

    1. Ubuntu Bionic
    
        1. Installing vcstool and colcon
        
            1. Use .deb packages in Ubuntu to install vcstool and colcon
            
        2. Getting the sources
        3. Install dependencies
        4. Building the Ignition Libraries _\(jump to c. to complete\)_
        
    2. MacOS Mojave \(10.14\)
    
        1. Install python3, vcstool, mercurial and colcon
        2. Getting the sources
        3. Install dependencies
        4. Building the Ignition Libraries
        
    3. Building the colcon workspace
    4. Using the workspace
    5. Troubleshooting
    
        1. _Linux \(if there were any\)_
        
            1. _issue title_
            
        2. MacOS
        
            1. Unable to find `urdf_model.h` error
            2. Unable to load .dylib file
            
        
    

‌

I believe this is the best way to eliminate as much jumping around between sections as possible. Unfortunately, the “Getting the sources” section is 100% copied between the two platforms. Repeating entire sections is not ideal, but in this case it does provide three significant benefits:

* allows  the two platforms to be as separated as possible 
* allows the logical ordering of putting “Getting the sources” before “Install dependencies”
* makes it so the “Building the Ignition Libraries” section doesn’t have to be it’s own section that breaks up between platforms

If anyone needs more convincing, I can put together a diagram illustrating how much a reader would have to jump around between sections to follow their platform’s installation before vs. now when we repeat “Getting the sources”.

‌
values.title: New organization for install page

If anyone needs more convincing, I can put together a diagram illustrating how much a reader would have to jump around between sections to follow their platform’s installation before vs. now when we repeat “Getting the sources”.

‌
summary.html:
This is the outline I came up with to organize the installation page better:

  1. Option 1: Binary Installation

    1. Ubuntu Bionic
    2. MacOS Mojave (10.14)
    3. Using the workspace (finished, no jumps necessary)

  2. Option 2: Source Installation

    1. Ubuntu Bionic

      1. Installing vcstool and colcon

        1. Use .deb packages in Ubuntu to install vcstool and colcon

      2. Getting the sources

      3. Install dependencies
      4. Building the Ignition Libraries (jump to c. to complete)

    2. MacOS Mojave (10.14)

      1. Install python3, vcstool, mercurial and colcon
      2. Getting the sources
      3. Install dependencies
      4. Building the Ignition Libraries

    3. Building the colcon workspace

    4. Using the workspace

    5. Troubleshooting

      1. Linux (if there were any)

        1. issue title

      2. MacOS

        1. Unable to find urdf_model.h error
        2. Unable to load .dylib file

‌

I believe this is the best way to eliminate as much jumping around between sections as possible. Unfortunately, the “Getting the sources” section is 100% copied between the two platforms. Repeating entire sections is not ideal, but in this case it does provide three significant benefits:

  • allows the two platforms to be as separated as possible
  • allows the logical ordering of putting “Getting the sources” before “Install dependencies”
  • makes it so the “Building the Ignition Libraries” section doesn’t have to be it’s own section that breaks up between platforms

If anyone needs more convincing, I can put together a diagram illustrating how much a reader would have to jump around between sections to follow their platform’s installation before vs. now when we repeat “Getting the sources”.

‌

values.description:
@{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8} Couple questions: What do you think about adding uninstall instructions for binaries? I know it’ll just be a couple lines, but so are the source instructions so it seems reasonable.

Also, I’m not sure about the first troubleshooting section \(currently in install\_osx\_src.md starting on line 198\) “Unable to create the rendering window“. Does that apply only to macOS, or Ubuntu, or both?
values.title: Initial commit for new installation pages

summary.raw:
@{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8} Couple questions: What do you think about adding uninstall instructions for binaries? I know it’ll just be a couple lines, but so are the source instructions so it seems reasonable.

Also, I’m not sure about the first troubleshooting section \(currently in install\_osx\_src.md starting on line 198\) “Unable to create the rendering window“. Does that apply only to macOS, or Ubuntu, or both?
summary.html:
@Louise Poubel Couple questions: What do you think about adding uninstall instructions for binaries? I know it’ll just be a couple lines, but so are the source instructions so it seems reasonable.

Also, I’m not sure about the first troubleshooting section (currently in install_osx_src.md starting on line 198) “Unable to create the rendering window“. Does that apply only to macOS, or Ubuntu, or both?
